Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: SPAL3D -- Design and Implementation of a Type System for Three-Dimensional Spatial Data in Databases

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective is the design and implementation of a new formal data model and type system called Spatial Algebra 3D (SPAL3D) for three-dimensional (3D) spatial data in database systems and geographical information systems. While these systems so far focus on two-dimensional spatial entities only, despite many potential geoscience applications, three-dimensional (3D) data modeling and data management have so far been rather neglected. This research and education project explores the fundamental properties and the structure of complex 3D spatial data from a data management and database perspective, identifies their most important operations and predicates, and supports their treatment in data modeling, representation, storing, manipulation, and querying. SPAL3D is extensible, makes it possible to add new types and operations, and can be plugged into different DBMS. The solution approach is based on three three fundamental pillars: (i) an abstract data model
(SPAL3D-A) for the rigorous, mathematical definition of a comprehensive type system (algebra) for 3D spatial data including volumes, surfaces, and 3D lines, (ii) a discrete data model (SPAL3D-D) for the design of effective geometric data structures for the 3D spatial data types of SPAL3D-A and on efficient geometric algorithms on these data structures for the 3D operations and predicates of SPAL3D-A, and (iii) the implementation and database integration (SPAL3D-I) of the data structures and algorithms of SPAL3D-D as abstract data types into several extensible DBMS data models and query languages.

The results of this research are expected to have broad impact on applications in areas where the third dimension of spatial data plays an important role. Examples are geographical information systems, meteorology, hurricane research, environmental monitoring, pollution control, soil science, water supply and distribution, fishery monitoring and simulating, geology, soil engineering and mining, earthquake modeling and simulation, to name only a few. The educational component of this project includes specialized classes that focus on important aspects of this project, the creation and use of new GIS educational materials, and the involvement of students in interdisciplinary research. The project Website
(http://www.cise.ufl.edu/~mschneid/Research/FundedResearchProjects/NSF-IIS-0915914/spal3d)
is used for the dissemination of research results, educational material, publications, generated data sets, produced software, and other information of interest.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our world is three-dimensional. The management, storage, processing, manipulation, and querying of three-dimensional geometric data is needed in many scientific applications like the geosciences (e.g., geography, geodesy, climatology, meteorology, hurricane research) and the life sciences (e.g., biology, genetics). However, data management systems tailored to the handling of spatial or geometric data like spatial databases and Geographical Information Systems (GIS) represent our world in a predominantly two-dimensional manner. This project has explored the extension and generalization of these systems to the third dimension. One result is a type system called Spatial Algebra 3D (SPAL3D). SPAL3D introduces new spatial data types (e.g., volume, surface), spatial operations (e.g., intersection, convex hull), and spatial relationships (e.g., overlap, north_of, above) for three-dimensional data at the conceptual level and corresponding novel geometric data structures and geometric algorithms at the implementation level. A special focus has been on topological relationships (e.g., overlap, disjoint, inside, meet) for three-dimensional spatial objects and led to the Neighborhood Configuration Model (NCM), which offers a more fine-grained view on such relationships than previous models. The embedding of SPAL3D concepts into the query languages of database systems allows the user to store, retrieve, query, and manipulate three-dimensional spatial objects.

Spatial networks, i.e., networks embedded in space, are an ubiquitous spatial concept. Examples are road networks, transportation networks, phone networks, and power grids. Such networks have so far been modeled as two-dimensional entities. The Spatial Network Algebra (SNAL) provides a model for three-dimensional spatial networks. Adding the third dimension means that slopes and altitudes and additional three-dimensional operations and predicates can be considered. This has impact on a number of network operations like shortest path computations and spatial range queries. SNAL provides spatial data types for spatial networks that are parameterized by attribute types or label types describing thematic properties of network components (e.g., names of roads, names of junctions). Further, a number of operations has been defined on spatial networks that can be used for spatial network analysis and querying in a database context.

Scientists from disciplines like climate research, meteorology, and aviation have increasingly shown interest in studying the temporal evolution (i.e., movement, change of shape, growth/shrinking) of three-dimensional spatial objects like clouds, hurricanes, and icing fields over time. Such time-varying spatial objects are called 3D+time moving objects, and moving volumes are of particular interest. So far, moving objects databases have only assumed two-dimensional geometries that evolve over time, i.e., 2D+time moving objects, like moving points, moving lines, and moving regions. Technological and financial constraints do not allow the full data capture of moving volumes. Instead, only gridded input data at different altitudes and at different time instants (i.e., snapshots) are available. Approximation models have been developed that approximate the transitions between consecutive grids with respect to altitude and time and allow the scientist to derive approximated moving volumes consisting of components of equal labeling with respect to a selected theme like temperature, ice intensity, particle concentration, air pollution, or wind speed of tropical cyclones.

Three-dimensional point cloud management and computation is of interest i...

The management, storage, processing, manipulation, and querying of three-dimensional geometric data is needed in many scientific applications like the geosciences (e.g., geography, geodesy, climatology, meteorology, hurricane research) and the life sciences (e.g., biology, genetics). However, data management systems tailored to the handling of spatial or geometric data like spatial databases and Geographical Information Systems (GIS) represent our world in a predominantly two-dimensional manner. This project has explored the extension and generalization of these systems to the third dimension. One result is a type system called Spatial Algebra 3D (SPAL3D). SPAL3D introduces new spatial data types (e.g., volume, surface), spatial operations (e.g., intersection, convex hull), and spatial relationships (e.g., overlap, north_of, above) for three-dimensional data at the conceptual level and corresponding novel geometric data structures and geometric algorithms at the implementation level. A special focus has been on topological relationships (e.g., overlap, disjoint, inside, meet) for three-dimensional spatial objects and led to the Neighborhood Configuration Model (NCM), which offers a more fine-grained view on such relationships than previous models. The embedding of SPAL3D concepts into the query languages of database systems allows the user to store, retrieve, query, and manipulate three-dimensional spatial objects. Spatial networks, i.e., networks embedded in space, are an ubiquitous spatial concept. Examples are road networks, transportation networks, phone networks, and power grids. Such networks have so far been modeled as two-dimensional entities. The Spatial Network Algebra (SNAL) provides a model for three-dimensional spatial networks. Adding the third dimension means that slopes and altitudes and additional three-dimensional operations and predicates can be considered. This has impact on a number of network operations like shortest path computations and spatial range queries. SNAL provides spatial data types for spatial networks that are parameterized by attribute types or label types describing thematic properties of network components (e.g., names of roads, names of junctions). Further, a number of operations has been defined on spatial networks that can be used for spatial network analysis and querying in a database context. Scientists from disciplines like climate research, meteorology, and aviation have increasingly shown interest in studying the temporal evolution (i.e., movement, change of shape, growth/shrinking) of three-dimensional spatial objects like clouds, hurricanes, and icing fields over time. Such time-varying spatial objects are called 3D+time moving objects, and moving volumes are of particular interest. So far, moving objects databases have only assumed two-dimensional geometries that evolve over time, i.e., 2D+time moving objects, like moving points, moving lines, and moving regions. Technological and financial constraints do not allow the full data capture of moving volumes. Instead, only gridded input data at different altitudes and at different time instants (i.e., snapshots) are available. Approximation models have been developed that approximate the transitions between consecutive grids with respect to altitude and time and allow the scientist to derive approximated moving volumes consisting of components of equal labeling with respect to a selected theme like temperature, ice intensity, particle concentration, air pollution, or wind speed of tropical cyclones. Three-dimensional point cloud management and computation is of interest in many disciplines like geomatics, archaeology, geography, geology, geomorphology, seismology, forestry, remote sensing, and atmospheric physics. 3D point clouds are captured, for example, from 3D laser scans of buildings and from LIDAR technology to make high-resolution maps of tropical cyclones.
